name: Identify if a quantity is increased or decreased when multiplied by a fraction

skills.name: Identify if a quantity is increased or decreased when multiplied by a fraction

explanations.A: Not quite. Multiplying by 4/5 will make the answer less than 20. Remember, 1 is the only number we can multiply by if we do not want to change the starting value.
explanations.B: Not quite. Multiplying by 6/5 will make the answer more than 20. Remember, 1 is the only number we can multiply by if we do not want to change the starting value.
explanations.C: The only number that can make the statement correct is 1, as multiplying a number by one does not change the starting value. As 5/5 has a value of one, it must go in the box.
explanations.D: Not quite. Multiplying any number by 0 gives you an answer of 0. Remember, 1 is the only number we can multiply by if we do not want to change the starting value.

explanations.A: Not quite. Multiplying any number by 0 gives you an answer of 0. Remember, 1 is the only number we can multiply by if we do not want to change the starting value.
explanations.B: Not quite. Multiplying by 2/3 will make the answer less than 50. Remember, 1 is the only number we can multiply by if we do not want to change the starting value.
explanations.C: Not quite. Multiplying by 4/3 will make the answer more than 50. Remember, 1 is the only number we can multiply by if we do not want to change the starting value.
explanations.D: The only number that can make the statement correct is 1, as multiplying a number by one does not change the starting value. As 3/3 has a value of one, it must go in the box.

explanations.A: Not quite. To get an answer greater than 20 we would have to multiply by a number greater than one. 4/5 is smaller than one.
explanations.B: Multiplying by a number less than one will result in a value smaller than 20. As 4/5 is less than one we know that our answer will be less than (<) 20.
explanations.C: Not quite. To get an answer equal to 20 we would have to multiply 20 by one. 4/5 is smaller than one.
explanations.D: Not quite, our answer will either have to be greater than, equal to or less than 20. Remember multiplying by one will make the answer equal to 20. What do you think will happen if you multiply by a number less than one?

explanations.A: Not quite. To get an answer greater than 50 we would have to multiply by a number greater than one. 2/3 is smaller than one.
explanations.B: Multiplying by a number less than one will result in a value smaller than 50. As 2/3 is less than one we know that our answer will be less than (<) 50.
explanations.C: Not quite. To get an answer equal to 50 we would have to multiply 50 by one. 2/3 is smaller than one.
explanations.D: Not quite, our answer will either have to be greater than, equal to or less than 50. Remember multiplying by one will make the answer equal to 50. What do you think will happen if you multiply by a number less than one?

explanations.A: Multiplying by a number greater than one will result in a value larger than 18. As 4/3 is greater than one we know that our answer will be greater than 18, therefore Tom is correct.
explanations.B: Not quite. Multiplying 18 by one gives us an answer of 18. What do you think will happen if you multiply by a number greater than one?
explanations.C: Not quite, they can't both be correct. Multiplying 18 by one gives us an answer of 18. What do you think will happen if you multiply by a number greater than one?
explanations.D: Not quite. The only way for neither of them to be correct is if the answer was to equal 18. As we are not multiplying by one, this is not the case. 4/3 is greater than one, so do you think the answer will be less than or greater than 18?

explanations.A: Not quite. What is the value of the fraction 5/5? What will happen if you multiply 40 by this number?
explanations.B: Not quite. What is the value of the fraction 5/5? What will happen if you multiply 40 by this number?
explanations.C: Not quite, they can't both be correct. What is the value of the fraction 5/5? What will happen if you multiply 40 by this number?
explanations.D: Multiplying a number by one does not change the starting value. 5/5 is equal to one, therefore 40 x 5/5 equals 40, so both Tom and Katie are incorrect.

explanations.A: Not quite. To get an answer less than 3/4 we would have to multiply by a number smaller than one. 3/2 is bigger than one.
explanations.B: Multiplying by a number less than one will result in a value smaller than 3/4. All the other options are greater than or equal to one, so 2/3 is the only number that can make the calculation correct.
explanations.C: Not quite. To get an answer less than 3/4 we would have to multiply by a number smaller than one. 3/3 is equal to one.
explanations.D: Not quite. Multiplying by one will give us an answer equal to 3/4. Remember, to reduce the starting value you need to multiply by a number smaller than one.

explanations.A: Not quite. To get an answer less than 2/3 we would have to multiply by a number smaller than one. 8/8 is equal to one.
explanations.B: Not quite. To get an answer less than 2/3 we would have to multiply by a number smaller than one. 9/8 is bigger than one.
explanations.C: Multiplying by a number less than one will result in a value smaller than 2/3. All the other options are greater than or equal to one, so 5/8 is the only number that can make the calculation correct.
explanations.D: Not quite. Multiplying by one will give us an answer equal to 2/3. Remember, to reduce the starting value you need to multiply by a number smaller than one.

explanations.A: Not quite. The largest value will come from multiplying 7/8 by the largest number. 6/7 is the smallest number multiplying 7/8.
explanations.B: Not quite. Turn 8/7 into a mixed number and compare it to the other values multiplying 7/8.
explanations.C: Not quite. The largest value will come from multiplying 7/8 by the largest number. 7/7 is equal to one, which is not the largest number multiplying the 7/8.
explanations.D: The largest value will come from multiplying 7/8 by the largest number. 1 and 3/7 is equal to 10/7, which is the largest number multiplying the 7/8.

explanations.A: Not quite. Turn the 1 and 1/6 into an improper fraction and compare it to the other values multiplying 7/8.
explanations.B: Not quite. The largest value will come from multiplying 7/8 by the largest number. 5/6 is the smallest number multiplying 7/8.
explanations.C: The largest value will come from multiplying 7/8 by the largest number. 9/6 is equal to 1 and 3/6, which is the largest number multiplying the 7/8.
explanations.D: Not quite. The largest value will come from multiplying 7/8 by the largest number. 6/6 is equal to one, which is not the largest number multiplying the 7/8.
